Identifying Characteristics: Usually a rusty brown color with gray and black and usually have blackish-blue spots
In clear, light water, their skin gets darker, likewise in darker water, their skin gets lighter in color
Small, flattened limbs—flat head, wide tail, short/stubby legs, four distinct toes on each foot
Squeaky vocalization sounds like a dog’s bark
Size: Adults are typically 11’’ but can be as short as 8’’ and as long as 16’’
Biology: Mudpuppies take six years to reach sexual maturity
Mating typically takes place in autumn, though eggs are not laid till much later
Males deposit their spermatophores in the substratum of the environment
Females then pick them up with her cloaca and store them in a small specialized gland (spermatheca) until the eggs are fertilized
Females store the sperm until ovulation and internal fertilization takes place, usually just prior to deposition in the spring
Males leave the nest before the eggs are deposited
The female deposits between 20 and 200—average is about 60—eggs in a safe location, usually on the underside of a rock or log
The female stays with her eggs during the incubation period (around 40 days)
Hatchlings are about 2.5 cm long and grow to 3.6 cm before the yolk is completely consumed
Habitat: Freshwater ponds, lakes, streams, canals, reservoirs, and rivers
Lives close to the bottom of the water body where there are rocks and logs for shelter
Diet: Almost anything they can get in their mouths, including insects, earthworms, mollusks, and annelids
Range: Southern section of Canada, as far south as Georgia, and from the Midwest United States to North Carolina
